subject: RE: [junit] Junit and mock objects
msgSnippet: ... Take a look at http://mockobjects.sourceforge.net/javadoc/1.4/alt/java/net/Socket.html for an example: It s hard to mock java.net.Socket, because there
messageBody:
Pico Geyer wrote:

> In particular I found this statement from
> http://www.mockobjects.com/DynaMock.html:
> "We have found that mocking third party classes (and
> interfaces) over which we have no control causes problems in
> the long run. It is better to define an interfaces for your
> objects in terms of concepts in your application, and then
> implement them as wafer-thin adapters to the third party
> libraries. That has two benefits: (a) your objects are easier
> to understand, and (b) your application is not polluted with
> references to third party packages that might have to be
> replaced for non-technical reasons. You do not need to have
> full control over the entire codebase to follow this approach."
>
> I don't really understand what is meant by this.

Take a look at
http://mockobjects.sourceforge.net/javadoc/1.4/alt/java/net/Socket.html for
an example: It's hard to mock java.net.Socket, because there doesn't exist
an interface for it. So what they did is define their own interface, and
providing a wrapper for the java socket, and a mock implementation. (For the
latter, you could use EasyMock instead, of course.)

Does that help?

Cheers, Ilja
